importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update, indicating when the developments in James Comey's case were reported, showing the timeline of public attention on the legal challenge to his indictment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which the Justice Department initiated criminal charges against James Comey, marking the beginning of the legal proceedings that prompted his defense actions.

keyTakeAways: James Comey has launched two legal motions to have federal charges dismissed: one alleging a personal vendetta by President Donald Trump and another claiming the prosecutor, Lindsey Halligan, is illegitimate due to an unlawful appointment.

Comey’s attorneys argue that the prosecution is retaliatory, citing public statements by Trump attacking Comey in response to protected speech, and that the case constitutes an abuse of power under the U.S. Constitution.

Comey’s legal team asserts that Trump’s appointment of Lindsey Halligan as interim U.S. attorney violated the Appointments Clause of the Constitution by bypassing Senate confirmation, especially since the previous interim attorney had already completed 120 days.

The defense draws a parallel to a dismissed Trump indictment in Florida, where a similar unlawful appointment was found by a federal judge, suggesting precedent for dismissing Comey’s case on constitutional grounds.
Comey has pleaded not guilty to charges of providing false statements and obstructing a congressional proceeding.

Legal experts note that such claims of selective prosecution may be more likely to be considered by judges given the public history of Trump’s attacks on individuals targeted by the Justice Department.

summaryOfNewsArticle: James Comey, the former FBI director, has initiated a legal defense strategy to have federal charges brought against him for allegedly lying during congressional testimony dismissed, claiming the prosecution is a result of personal retaliation by President Donald Trump and that the prosecutor, Lindsey Halligan, was improperly appointed. His legal team argues that Trump's public attacks on Comey and the bypassing of Senate confirmation for Halligan's appointment violate constitutional provisions, including the Appointments Clause. They cite prior judicial rulings involving similar unlawful appointments, such as in the Trump Florida case involving Jack Smith, to support their claim. The case highlights broader concerns about political retaliation and executive overreach in the justice system.
title: James Comey launches major efforts to have case thrown out
